Problem:
Consider a system defined by a set of complex functions \\(z(t) = U(t)z_0\\), where \\(U(t)\\) is a unitary operator that evolves the state \\(z_0\\) over time t. We examine the effects of an integral transformation \\(T\\) defined by \\(T[z](t) = \\int_0^t V(s) z(s) \\, ds\\), where \\(V(s)\\) is another operator.

If the transformation \\(T\\) is applied to a function \\(z_0\\) at t = 0, and then the system is allowed to evolve under \\(z(t) = U(t)z_0\\) without further intervention, will the function \\(z(T)\\) at t = T be the same as if \\(z_0\\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\(z(t) = U(t)z_0\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\(T\\) modifies the initial conditions of the system by integrating the effect of \\(V(s)\\). This integration alters the trajectory of the state, so \\(z(T)\\) will be different because the new initial condition at each moment depends on the entire history up to that point, rather than just being directly evolved from \\(z_0\\).
